elements.content:
<ce:figure id="f0005">
<ce:label>Fig. 1</ce:label>
<ce:caption>
<ce:simple-para id="sp015" view="all">(a) Coordination environment of Zn(II) atoms in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> with the thermal ellipsoids drawn at the 30% probability level, hydrogen atoms and uncoordinated DMF molecules were omitted for clarity. (b) 2D (4, 4) layer structure linked by INAIP<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> ligands and Zn(II) centers, all 5-isonicotinamido groups were omitted for clarity. (c) 3D porous network of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> viewed along the <ce:italic>a</ce:italic>-axis. (d) Topological representation of the <ce:bold>rtl</ce:bold> structure of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>.</ce:simple-para>
</ce:caption>
<ce:link locator="gr1"></ce:link>
</ce:figure>
elements.clean_text:
Fig. 1

(a) Coordination environment of Zn(II) atoms in 1 with the thermal ellipsoids drawn at the 30% probability level, hydrogen atoms and uncoordinated DMF molecules were omitted for clarity. (b) 2D (4, 4) layer structure linked by INAIP2− ligands and Zn(II) centers, all 5-isonicotinamido groups were omitted for clarity. (c) 3D porous network of 1 viewed along the a-axis. (d) Topological representation of the rtl structure of 1.

elements.content:
<ce:figure id="f0010">
<ce:label>Fig. 2</ce:label>
<ce:caption>
<ce:simple-para id="sp020" view="all">(a) Coordination environment of Zn(II) atoms in <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> with the thermal ellipsoids drawn at the 30% probability level, hydrogen atoms and uncoordinated water molecules were omitted for clarity. (b) 2D layer structure linked by INAIP<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> ligands and Zn(II) centers, all 5-isonicotinamido groups were omitted for clarity (left) and the perfect kagomé lattice in <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> (right). (c) View of the 3D porous network along the <ce:italic>c</ce:italic>-axis in <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>. (d) Schematic illustration for the topology of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>.</ce:simple-para>
</ce:caption>
<ce:link locator="gr2"></ce:link>
</ce:figure>
elements.clean_text:
Fig. 2

(a) Coordination environment of Zn(II) atoms in 2 with the thermal ellipsoids drawn at the 30% probability level, hydrogen atoms and uncoordinated water molecules were omitted for clarity. (b) 2D layer structure linked by INAIP2− ligands and Zn(II) centers, all 5-isonicotinamido groups were omitted for clarity (left) and the perfect kagomé lattice in 2 (right). (c) View of the 3D porous network along the c-axis in 2. (d) Schematic illustration for the topology of 2.

elements.content:
<ce:figure id="f0015">
<ce:label>Fig. 3</ce:label>
<ce:caption>
<ce:simple-para id="sp025" view="all">(a) N<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> adsorption isotherm (77<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K) of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and (b) <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> (black and red curves represent adsorption and desorption, respectively). (c) CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> adsorption isotherm (195<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K) of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>. (Filled shapes: adsorption and open ones: desorption). (For interpretation of the references to colour in this figure legend, the reader is referred to the web version of this article.)</ce:simple-para>
</ce:caption>
<ce:link locator="gr3"></ce:link>
</ce:figure>
elements.clean_text:
Fig. 3

(a) N2 adsorption isotherm (77K) of 1 and (b) 2 (black and red curves represent adsorption and desorption, respectively). (c) CO2 adsorption isotherm (195K) of 1 and 2. (Filled shapes: adsorption and open ones: desorption). (For interpretation of the references to colour in this figure legend, the reader is referred to the web version of this article.)

The change of solvent leads to the formation of neutral frameworks with different structure, topology as well as different pore size and shape. The X-ray crystallographic structural analysis revealed that complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> is an unusual 3D architecture with (3, 6)-connected rutile (<ce:bold>rtl</ce:bold>) topology containing two-dimensional (2D) (4, 4) networks, while the 3D framework in <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> has (3, 6)-connected (4<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>·6)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(4<ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup>·6<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>·8<ce:sup loc="post">6</ce:sup>·10<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>) topology with 2D kagomé layers. elements.clean_text:
Graphical abstract







Research highlights
► Three-dimensional coordination frameworks with different pore size and shape. ► Solvent effect on formation and structure of metal-organic frameworks. ► Selective sorption behavior of CO2 over N2.
Abstract
Two new three-dimensional (3D) coordination polymers [Zn(INAIP)]·2DMF (1) and [Zn(INAIP)]·9H2O (2) have been synthesized by reactions of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O with 5-(isonicotinamido)isophthalic acid (H2INAIP) in N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF) and N,N-diethylformamide (DEF), respectively. The change of solvent leads to the formation of neutral frameworks with different structure, topology as well as different pore size and shape. The X-ray crystallographic structural analysis revealed that complex 1 is an unusual 3D architecture with (3, 6)-connected rutile (rtl) topology containing two-dimensional (2D) (4, 4) networks, while the 3D framework in 2 has (3, 6)-connected (42·6)2(44·62·86·103) topology with 2D kagomé layers. In addition, the stabilities, luminescence and adsorption properties of the complexes were investigated.

<ce:section-title>Introduction</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0005" view="all">In recent years, much effort has been devoted to the design and construction of coordination frameworks based on transition metal atoms and multifunctional bridging ligands owing to their diverse structures and interesting properties such as magnetism, electric conductivity, catalysis and molecular recognition . Particularly, porous coordination polymers (PCPs) have attracted considerable attention due to their potential applications in gas storage as functional porous solid materials . However, to successfully perform the porous functions, structural variations with different pore size and shape are essential. It is known that structure directing agents, well used in the synthesis of zeolite, are crucial and important for the construction of porous structures . Recently, we focus our attention on the reactions of varied metal salts with multicarboxylate and/or carboxamide containing ligands and the influence of solvent on the structure of the complexes was investigated . As an extension of our continuous research on the crystal engineering of metal–organic coordination polymers, in this study we have embarked on a program using a carboxamide containing ligand 5-(isonicotinamido)isophthalic acid (H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>INAIP)  to construct porous zinc(II) coordination polymers [Zn(INAIP)]·2DMF (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>), [Zn(INAIP)]·9H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>) in <ce:italic>N,N</ce:italic>-dimethylformamide (DMF) and <ce:italic>N,N</ce:italic>-diethylformamide (DEF). The thermal stability, fluorescence as well as adsorption properties of the complexes were investigated.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Introduction
In recent years, much effort has been devoted to the design and construction of coordination frameworks based on transition metal atoms and multifunctional bridging ligands owing to their diverse structures and interesting properties such as magnetism, electric conductivity, catalysis and molecular recognition . Particularly, porous coordination polymers (PCPs) have attracted considerable attention due to their potential applications in gas storage as functional porous solid materials . However, to successfully perform the porous functions, structural variations with different pore size and shape are essential. It is known that structure directing agents, well used in the synthesis of zeolite, are crucial and important for the construction of porous structures . Recently, we focus our attention on the reactions of varied metal salts with multicarboxylate and/or carboxamide containing ligands and the influence of solvent on the structure of the complexes was investigated . As an extension of our continuous research on the crystal engineering of metal–organic coordination polymers, in this study we have embarked on a program using a carboxamide containing ligand 5-(isonicotinamido)isophthalic acid (H2INAIP)  to construct porous zinc(II) coordination polymers [Zn(INAIP)]·2DMF (1), [Zn(INAIP)]·9H2O (2) in N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF) and N,N-diethylformamide (DEF). The thermal stability, fluorescence as well as adsorption properties of the complexes were investigated.

<ce:section-title>Experimental</ce:section-title><ce:section-title>Materials and measurements</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0010" view="all">All commercially available chemicals are of reagent grade and were used as received without further purification. Solvents were purified according to the standard methods. The ligand H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>INAIP was prepared as reported previously . C, H and N analyses were made on a Perkin–Elmer 240C elemental analyzer at the analysis center of Nanjing University. FT-IR spectra were recorded on a Bruker model Vector22 FT-IR spectrophotometer using KBr disks. Thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) were performed on a simultaneous SDT 2960 thermal analyzer under nitrogen with a heating rate of 10<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C min<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>. Power X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns were measured on a Shimadzu XRD-6000 X-ray diffractometer with Cu Kα (<ce:italic>λ</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1.5418<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å) radiation at room temperature. The luminescent spectra for the solid powdered samples were recorded at room temperature on an Aminco Bowman Series 2 spectrophotometer with xenon arc lamp as the light source. In the measurements of the emission and excitation spectra, the pass width was 5.0<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm. All the measurements were carried out under the same conditions. Nitrogen (N<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>) and carbon dioxide (CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>) sorption experiments were carried out on a Belsorp-max volumetric gas sorption instrument.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Experimental
Materials and measurements
All commercially available chemicals are of reagent grade and were used as received without further purification. Solvents were purified according to the standard methods. The ligand H2INAIP was prepared as reported previously . C, H and N analyses were made on a Perkin–Elmer 240C elemental analyzer at the analysis center of Nanjing University. FT-IR spectra were recorded on a Bruker model Vector22 FT-IR spectrophotometer using KBr disks. Thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) were performed on a simultaneous SDT 2960 thermal analyzer under nitrogen with a heating rate of 10°C min−1. Power X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns were measured on a Shimadzu XRD-6000 X-ray diffractometer with Cu Kα (λ
=1.5418Å) radiation at room temperature. The luminescent spectra for the solid powdered samples were recorded at room temperature on an Aminco Bowman Series 2 spectrophotometer with xenon arc lamp as the light source. In the measurements of the emission and excitation spectra, the pass width was 5.0nm. All the measurements were carried out under the same conditions. Nitrogen (N2) and carbon dioxide (CO2) sorption experiments were carried out on a Belsorp-max volumetric gas sorption instrument.

Synthesis of the complexes
Synthesis of [Zn(INAIP)]·2DMF (1)
A mixture containing Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (30.1mg, 0.1mmol), H2INAIP (28.6mg, 0.1mmol) dissolved in 6mL DMF was sealed in a 16mL Teflon lined stainless steel container and heated at 120°C for 5days. Pale yellow block crystals of 1 were collected by filtration and washed by DMF for several times with a yield of 36%. Anal. Calcd for C20H22ZnN4O7: C, 48.45; H, 4.47; N, 11.30%. Found: C, 48.52; H, 4.42; N, 11.38%. IR (KBr pellet, cm−1): 3451(s), 1672(m), 1620(s), 1570(s), 1425(m), 1368(m), 1288(w), 1066(w), 1031(w), 851(w), 780(w), 731(m), 687(w), 610(w).

Light brown crystals of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> were collected by filtration and washed by DEF for several times with a yield of 42%. Anal. Calcd for C<ce:inf loc="post">14</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">26</ce:inf>ZnN<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">14</ce:inf>: C, 32.86; H, 5.12; N, 5.47%. Found: C, 32.93; H, 5.21; N, 5.41%. IR (KBr pellet, cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>): 3424(m), 1649(s), 1560(s), 1423(s), 1365(s), 1286(m), 1066(w), 1029(w), 851(w), 779(w), 725(m), 602(w).</ce:para>

Synthesis of [Zn(INAIP)]·9H2O (2)
Complex 2 was synthesized in the similar way to that described for preparation of 1, except that the reaction solvent was changed to DEF. Light brown crystals of 2 were collected by filtration and washed by DEF for several times with a yield of 42%. Anal. Calcd for C14H26ZnN2O14: C, 32.86; H, 5.12; N, 5.47%. Found: C, 32.93; H, 5.21; N, 5.41%. IR (KBr pellet, cm−1): 3424(m), 1649(s), 1560(s), 1423(s), 1365(s), 1286(m), 1066(w), 1029(w), 851(w), 779(w), 725(m), 602(w).

<ce:section-title>Crystal structure determination</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0025" view="all">The crystallographic data collections for complexes <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> were carried out on a Rigaku RAXIS-RAPID Imaging Plate diffractometer with graphite-monochromated Mo-Kα radiation (<ce:italic>λ</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>0.71075 Å) at 200<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K. The structures of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> were solved by direct methods using SIR92 and SHELX97 , respectively, and expanded using Fourier techniques . All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically using SHELXL97 . All the hydrogen atoms except for those of water molecules were generated geometrically and refined isotropically using the riding model, while those of water molecules in <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> were not found. All calculations were performed using the CrystalStructure crystallographic software package . Each atom of C71, C72 and C73 in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> disordered into two positions with site occupancy factors (sof) of 0.516(15) and 0.484(17), respectively. Each atom of C61, C62, C63, C81, C82, C83, N6, N8, O6 and O8 in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> has sof of 0.50. The 5-isonicotinamido groups in <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> are twofold disordered (each atom of C11, C12, C13, C14, C15, C16 and O1 has sof of 0.50). On the other hand, only 2.8 H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O in <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> are refined, the other highly disordered water molecules could not be determined from crystallographic analysis. Thus, the content of non-coordinated water molecules in <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> was quantitatively deduced by elemental analysis and TGA. The details of the crystal parameters, data collection and refinement for complexes <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> are summarized in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="t0005"></ce:float-anchor>, and selected bond lengths and angles with their estimated standard deviations are listed in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="t0010"></ce:float-anchor>.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Crystal structure determination
The crystallographic data collections for complexes 1 and 2 were carried out on a Rigaku RAXIS-RAPID Imaging Plate diffractometer with graphite-monochromated Mo-Kα radiation (λ
=0.71075 Å) at 200K. The structures of 1 and 2 were solved by direct methods using SIR92 and SHELX97 , respectively, and expanded using Fourier techniques . All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically using SHELXL97 . All the hydrogen atoms except for those of water molecules were generated geometrically and refined isotropically using the riding model, while those of water molecules in 2 were not found. All calculations were performed using the CrystalStructure crystallographic software package . Each atom of C71, C72 and C73 in 1 disordered into two positions with site occupancy factors (sof) of 0.516(15) and 0.484(17), respectively. Each atom of C61, C62, C63, C81, C82, C83, N6, N8, O6 and O8 in 1 has sof of 0.50. The 5-isonicotinamido groups in 2 are twofold disordered (each atom of C11, C12, C13, C14, C15, C16 and O1 has sof of 0.50). On the other hand, only 2.8 H2O in 2 are refined, the other highly disordered water molecules could not be determined from crystallographic analysis. Thus, the content of non-coordinated water molecules in 2 was quantitatively deduced by elemental analysis and TGA. The details of the crystal parameters, data collection and refinement for complexes 1 and 2 are summarized in 
, and selected bond lengths and angles with their estimated standard deviations are listed in 
.

elements.content:
<ce:section-title>Results and discussion</ce:section-title><ce:section-title>Crystal structures of complexes <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>
</ce:section-title><ce:section-title>Crystal structure of [Zn(INAIP)]·2DMF (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>)</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0030" view="all">The X-ray crystallographic analysis revealed that <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> is a 3D porous architecture containing 2D (4, 4) networks pillared by 5-isonicotinamido groups. The asymmetric unit of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> consists of one Zn(II) atom, one INAIP<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> ligand and two non-coordinated DMF molecules. As shown in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0005"></ce:float-anchor>a, each Zn(II) atom with square-pyramidal coordination geometry is coordinated by four carboxylate oxygen atoms (O31, O32C, O51B and O52D) at the basal plane and one pyridyl nitrogen one (N11A) at the apical position. Two Zn(II) atoms are bridged by four carboxylate groups to generate a [Zn<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(OCO)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>] dinuclear paddle-wheel secondary building units (SBUs). When the coordination of 5-isonicotinamido group is neglected, the SBUs are interlinked together via the bridging INAIP<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> ligands resulting in formation of a metal-carboxylate 2D network with (4, 4) topology regarding the dinuclear SBU as a node (b). The 2D layers are further joined together by 5-isonicotinamido groups via the Zn–N coordination to result in formation of the 3D framework () with one-dimensional (1D) channels along the <ce:italic>a</ce:italic>-axis as shown in c. The cavities of the 1D channel with an effective pore diameter of 4.5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å are occupied by DMF molecules. By omitting the DMF molecules, PLATON  calculations revealed that the 3D porous structure of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> is composed of large voids of 1456.5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup> representing 57.5% per unit cell volume.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Results and discussion
Crystal structures of complexes 1 and 2

Crystal structure of [Zn(INAIP)]·2DMF (1)
The X-ray crystallographic analysis revealed that 1 is a 3D porous architecture containing 2D (4, 4) networks pillared by 5-isonicotinamido groups. The asymmetric unit of 1 consists of one Zn(II) atom, one INAIP2− ligand and two non-coordinated DMF molecules. As shown in 
a, each Zn(II) atom with square-pyramidal coordination geometry is coordinated by four carboxylate oxygen atoms (O31, O32C, O51B and O52D) at the basal plane and one pyridyl nitrogen one (N11A) at the apical position. Two Zn(II) atoms are bridged by four carboxylate groups to generate a [Zn2(OCO)4] dinuclear paddle-wheel secondary building units (SBUs). When the coordination of 5-isonicotinamido group is neglected, the SBUs are interlinked together via the bridging INAIP2− ligands resulting in formation of a metal-carboxylate 2D network with (4, 4) topology regarding the dinuclear SBU as a node (b). The 2D layers are further joined together by 5-isonicotinamido groups via the Zn–N coordination to result in formation of the 3D framework () with one-dimensional (1D) channels along the a-axis as shown in c. The cavities of the 1D channel with an effective pore diameter of 4.5Å are occupied by DMF molecules. By omitting the DMF molecules, PLATON  calculations revealed that the 3D porous structure of 1 is composed of large voids of 1456.5Å3 representing 57.5% per unit cell volume.

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0035" view="all">To well understand the topology of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, it is necessary to simplify the building units. The above mentioned dinuclear (Zn<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>) subunit can be regarded as a six-connected node since each Zn<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> is surrounded by six (four carboxylate and two pyridyl groups) adjacent INAIP<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> ligands (). At the same time, each INAIP<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> ligand can be considered as a three-connector to link three Zn<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> subunits through its two carboxylate and one pyridyl groups. Consequently, according to the calculation of TOPOS , the framework of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> belongs to a binodal (3, 6)-connected <ce:bold>rtl</ce:bold> topology net (d), with Point (Schläfli) symbol of (4·6<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(4<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>·6<ce:sup loc="post">10</ce:sup>·8<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: To well understand the topology of 1, it is necessary to simplify the building units. The above mentioned dinuclear (Zn2) subunit can be regarded as a six-connected node since each Zn2 is surrounded by six (four carboxylate and two pyridyl groups) adjacent INAIP2− ligands (). At the same time, each INAIP2− ligand can be considered as a three-connector to link three Zn2 subunits through its two carboxylate and one pyridyl groups. Consequently, according to the calculation of TOPOS , the framework of 1 belongs to a binodal (3, 6)-connected rtl topology net (d), with Point (Schläfli) symbol of (4·62)2(42·610·83).

elements.content:
<ce:section-title>Crystal structure of [Zn(INAIP)]·9H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>)</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0040" view="all">When the reaction solvent was changed from DMF used in preparation of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> to DEF, complex <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> with different structure and topology was obtained. Single crystal X-ray crystallographic analysis revealed that compound <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> crystallizes in trigonal space group <ce:italic>R</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>−<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>3<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>m. Each Zn(II) atom in <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> (
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0010"></ce:float-anchor>a) has similar coordination environment and geometry with that in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> (a), and there are also [Zn<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(OCO)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>] dinuclear paddle-wheel SBUs. However, the [Zn<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(OCO)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>] SBUs in <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> are connected together by INAIP<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> ligands omitting the coordination of 5-isonicotinamido group to give a 2D kagomé lattice in the <ce:italic>ab</ce:italic> plane composed of [Zn<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(OCO)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> triangles and [Zn<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(OCO)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf> hexagons (b), rather than the 2D (4, 4) net in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> (b). In addition, in contrast to the presence of DMF in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, no DEF molecules were detected in <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>. The 2D kagomé networks are further connected together by the 5-isonicotinamido groups of the INAIP<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> ligands to generate a 3D porous framework (). PLATON  analysis revealed that the 1D channels with effective pore diameter of 4.0 Å in <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> are composed of large voids of 6959.4<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup> (55.7% per unit cell volume) (c). Similar topological analysis was carried out to get insight of the structure of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>. As discussed above, each INAIP<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> ligand and each Zn<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> subunit can be regarded as three-connector and six-connecting node, respectively. Thus, the resulting structure of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> is a binodal (3, 6)-connecting net as shown in d with Point (Schläfli) symbol of (4<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>·6)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(4<ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup>·6<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>·8<ce:sup loc="post">6</ce:sup>·10<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>) calculated by TOPOS .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Crystal structure of [Zn(INAIP)]·9H2O (2)
When the reaction solvent was changed from DMF used in preparation of 1 to DEF, complex 2 with different structure and topology was obtained. Single crystal X-ray crystallographic analysis revealed that compound 2 crystallizes in trigonal space group R
−3m. Each Zn(II) atom in 2 (
a) has similar coordination environment and geometry with that in 1 (a), and there are also [Zn2(OCO)4] dinuclear paddle-wheel SBUs. However, the [Zn2(OCO)4] SBUs in 2 are connected together by INAIP2− ligands omitting the coordination of 5-isonicotinamido group to give a 2D kagomé lattice in the ab plane composed of [Zn2(OCO)2]3 triangles and [Zn2(OCO)2]6 hexagons (b), rather than the 2D (4, 4) net in 1 (b). In addition, in contrast to the presence of DMF in 1, no DEF molecules were detected in 2. The 2D kagomé networks are further connected together by the 5-isonicotinamido groups of the INAIP2− ligands to generate a 3D porous framework (). PLATON  analysis revealed that the 1D channels with effective pore diameter of 4.0 Å in 2 are composed of large voids of 6959.4Å3 (55.7% per unit cell volume) (c). Similar topological analysis was carried out to get insight of the structure of 2. As discussed above, each INAIP2− ligand and each Zn2 subunit can be regarded as three-connector and six-connecting node, respectively. Thus, the resulting structure of 2 is a binodal (3, 6)-connecting net as shown in d with Point (Schläfli) symbol of (42·6)2(44·62·86·103) calculated by TOPOS .

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0045" view="all">It is interesting to note that just by using different solvents under the same reaction conditions two compounds <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> with different structures have been obtained by the same ligand and metal salt. More interestingly, both compounds <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> have neutral 3D porous frameworks with different shape, and the former one is constructed by 2D (4, 4) metal-carboxylate network, while the later one contains a 2D Kagomé net connected by the benzenebicarboxylate of the ligand. The difference between <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> implies that the reaction solvent plays crucial role in the formation of the porous frameworks.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: It is interesting to note that just by using different solvents under the same reaction conditions two compounds 1 and 2 with different structures have been obtained by the same ligand and metal salt. More interestingly, both compounds 1 and 2 have neutral 3D porous frameworks with different shape, and the former one is constructed by 2D (4, 4) metal-carboxylate network, while the later one contains a 2D Kagomé net connected by the benzenebicarboxylate of the ligand. The difference between 1 and 2 implies that the reaction solvent plays crucial role in the formation of the porous frameworks.

elements.content: <ce:section-title>TGA, powder X-ray diffraction and photoluminescent properties</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0050" view="all">The results of thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) indicate that compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> lost its non-coordinated DMF molecules in the temperature range of 30–190<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C () . The weight loss of 29.75% is consistent with calculated one of 29.48%. After the loss of the DMF molecules, the 3D framework is stable up to 340<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C, followed by further weight loss at high temperature. The end product of decomposition of complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> is ZnO with weight percentage 16.33% (calculated: 16.42%). A total weight loss of 31.11% was observed for <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> in the temperature range of 25–275<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C, which can be attributed to the loss of lattice water molecules (calcd 30.97%), and the decomposition of the residue takes place at about 350<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C, the end product of decomposition is also ZnO for <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> with weight percentage of 16.62% (calculated: 15.90%). PXRD was used to check the purity of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> () .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
TGA, powder X-ray diffraction and photoluminescent properties
The results of thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) indicate that compound 1 lost its non-coordinated DMF molecules in the temperature range of 30–190°C () . The weight loss of 29.75% is consistent with calculated one of 29.48%. After the loss of the DMF molecules, the 3D framework is stable up to 340°C, followed by further weight loss at high temperature. The end product of decomposition of complex 1 is ZnO with weight percentage 16.33% (calculated: 16.42%). A total weight loss of 31.11% was observed for 2 in the temperature range of 25–275°C, which can be attributed to the loss of lattice water molecules (calcd 30.97%), and the decomposition of the residue takes place at about 350°C, the end product of decomposition is also ZnO for 2 with weight percentage of 16.62% (calculated: 15.90%). PXRD was used to check the purity of 1 and 2 () .

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0055" view="all">The photoluminescent properties of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> and Na<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>INAIP were investigated in the solid state at room temperature. As shown in , intense emission bands were observed at 465<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm (<ce:italic>λ<ce:inf loc="post">ex</ce:inf>
</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>390<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm) for Na<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>INAIP, 481<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm (<ce:italic>λ<ce:inf loc="post">ex</ce:inf>
</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>390<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm) for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, 468<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm (<ce:italic>λ<ce:inf loc="post">ex</ce:inf>
</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>390<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm) for <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>. The emissions in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> can be attributed to neither metal-to-ligand charge transfer (MLCT) nor ligand-to-metal charge transfer (LMCT) since the Zn(II) ions are in d<ce:sup loc="post">10</ce:sup> configuration and difficult to oxidize or to reduce. Therefore the emissions observed in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> are tentatively assigned to the <ce:italic>π − π</ce:italic>
<ce:sup loc="post">*</ce:sup> intraligand photoluminescence due to its resemblance to that of Na<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>INAIP. On the other hand, the emission band intensity for complexes <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> is increased and decreased, respectively, in comparison to the one of Na<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>INAIP, which may be ascribed to the quenching effect of water molecules in <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>. The results suggest that the complexes <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> may be good candidate of potential blue-fluorescent materials, since they have high thermal stability and are insoluble in common solvents.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
The photoluminescent properties of 1, 2 and Na2INAIP were investigated in the solid state at room temperature. As shown in , intense emission bands were observed at 465nm (λex

=390nm) for Na2INAIP, 481nm (λex

=390nm) for 1, 468nm (λex

=390nm) for 2. The emissions in 1 and 2 can be attributed to neither metal-to-ligand charge transfer (MLCT) nor ligand-to-metal charge transfer (LMCT) since the Zn(II) ions are in d10 configuration and difficult to oxidize or to reduce. Therefore the emissions observed in 1 and 2 are tentatively assigned to the π − π
* intraligand photoluminescence due to its resemblance to that of Na2INAIP. On the other hand, the emission band intensity for complexes 1 and 2 is increased and decreased, respectively, in comparison to the one of Na2INAIP, which may be ascribed to the quenching effect of water molecules in 2. The results suggest that the complexes 1 and 2 may be good candidate of potential blue-fluorescent materials, since they have high thermal stability and are insoluble in common solvents.

elements.content:
<ce:section-title>Gas sorption properties</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0060" view="all">As discussed above, the frameworks <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> are stable up to 340<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C, thus gas adsorption property of the complexes can be expected. Before gas adsorption tests, activation to remove the guest molecules from the pores by heating under vacuum is a required pretreatment and the as-synthesized crystal samples were heated at an optimized temperature of 140<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C for 20<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>h. To verify whether the framework of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> can be sustained after the removal of the solvent molecules, PXRD patterns were measured (). The framework of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> still has crystallinity after removing the solvent molecules, but the PXRD pattern of the activated sample is different from the as-synthesized one which may be attributed to the framework dynamics of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>. The crystalline solid of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> can be re-generated by immersing the activated sample in 10<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL DMF for 12<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>h as indicated by the PXRD measurements () . The results show that the host framework of complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> is flexible enough to change its structure depending on the nature of the guest molecules, and the framework transformations are reversible. While complex <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> shows good crystallinity after removing the guest water molecules and the PXRD pattern of the activated sample shifts and becomes broad compared with the as-synthesized one (), therefore, the gas sorption isotherms of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> are investigated. The N<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> adsorption isotherms for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> are shown in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0015"></ce:float-anchor>a and b, it can be seen that no N<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> uptake was observed at 77<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, hysteresis was observed between the adsorption and desorption curves down to the lowest attainable pressure, which are characteristic for type-H3 sorption . However, significant amounts of CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> (195<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K) were adsorbed (c) and both isotherms present typical type-I curves , which is the characteristic of microporous material. The amounts of adsorbed CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> increase abruptly at the beginning and reach to 60.90<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup> (STP)/g (1.40<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol/g) at 1.0 atom for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, 43.19<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup> (STP)/g (0.82<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol/g) for <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, approximately 0.48 CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> and 0.23 CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> molecules per formula unit were adsorbed for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>. Fitting the BET equations to the CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> adsorption isotherm gave estimated surface areas of 119 and 68<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>m<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>/g for complexes <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, respectively. The gas sorption isotherms show distinct hysteresis between the adsorption–desorption curves, which must be attributed to the intercrystalline voids . It is noteworthy that no N<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> were adsorbed in spite of the channel size larger than the kinetic diameter of N<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> (3.64<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å), thus, the selective sorption behaviors of CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> over N<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> are attributed to the significant quadrupole moment of CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> (−1.4<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>×<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>10<ce:sup loc="post">−39</ce:sup>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Cm<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>), which induces specific interactions with the host framework . Considering the great current interest of CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> adsorption/separation, the present work provides nice example of selective sorption behaviors of CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> over N<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> that is not size-controlled, but quadrupole moment induced .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Gas sorption properties
As discussed above, the frameworks 1 and 2 are stable up to 340°C, thus gas adsorption property of the complexes can be expected. Before gas adsorption tests, activation to remove the guest molecules from the pores by heating under vacuum is a required pretreatment and the as-synthesized crystal samples were heated at an optimized temperature of 140°C for 20h. To verify whether the framework of 1 can be sustained after the removal of the solvent molecules, PXRD patterns were measured (). The framework of 1 still has crystallinity after removing the solvent molecules, but the PXRD pattern of the activated sample is different from the as-synthesized one which may be attributed to the framework dynamics of 1. The crystalline solid of 1 can be re-generated by immersing the activated sample in 10mL DMF for 12h as indicated by the PXRD measurements () . The results show that the host framework of complex 1 is flexible enough to change its structure depending on the nature of the guest molecules, and the framework transformations are reversible. While complex 2 shows good crystallinity after removing the guest water molecules and the PXRD pattern of the activated sample shifts and becomes broad compared with the as-synthesized one (), therefore, the gas sorption isotherms of 1 and 2 are investigated. The N2 adsorption isotherms for 1 and 2 are shown in 
a and b, it can be seen that no N2 uptake was observed at 77K for 1 and 2, hysteresis was observed between the adsorption and desorption curves down to the lowest attainable pressure, which are characteristic for type-H3 sorption . However, significant amounts of CO2 (195K) were adsorbed (c) and both isotherms present typical type-I curves , which is the characteristic of microporous material. The amounts of adsorbed CO2 increase abruptly at the beginning and reach to 60.90cm3 (STP)/g (1.40mmol/g) at 1.0 atom for 1, 43.19cm3 (STP)/g (0.82mmol/g) for 2, approximately 0.48 CO2 and 0.23 CO2 molecules per formula unit were adsorbed for 1 and 2. Fitting the BET equations to the CO2 adsorption isotherm gave estimated surface areas of 119 and 68m2/g for complexes 1 and 2, respectively. The gas sorption isotherms show distinct hysteresis between the adsorption–desorption curves, which must be attributed to the intercrystalline voids . It is noteworthy that no N2 were adsorbed in spite of the channel size larger than the kinetic diameter of N2 (3.64Å), thus, the selective sorption behaviors of CO2 over N2 are attributed to the significant quadrupole moment of CO2 (−1.4×10−39
Cm2), which induces specific interactions with the host framework . Considering the great current interest of CO2 adsorption/separation, the present work provides nice example of selective sorption behaviors of CO2 over N2 that is not size-controlled, but quadrupole moment induced .

elements.content: <ce:section-title>Conclusion</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0065" view="all">In summary, we have successfully synthesized two porous Zn(II) coordination frameworks with INAIP<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> by simply changing the solvent in the reaction system. The resulting compounds give neutral frameworks with different pore size and shape tuned by the solvent molecules, which imply that the solvents play a crucial role in the synthesis of various kinds of frameworks. In addition, the adsorption of complexes <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> indicate that they have selective adsorptions of CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> over N<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> after the removal of the guest molecules within the pores.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion
In summary, we have successfully synthesized two porous Zn(II) coordination frameworks with INAIP2− by simply changing the solvent in the reaction system. The resulting compounds give neutral frameworks with different pore size and shape tuned by the solvent molecules, which imply that the solvents play a crucial role in the synthesis of various kinds of frameworks. In addition, the adsorption of complexes 1 and 2 indicate that they have selective adsorptions of CO2 over N2 after the removal of the guest molecules within the pores.

metadata.title: Porous zinc(II) frameworks with 5-(isonicotinamido)isophthalate: Syntheses, structures and properties
